text: We'll hear argument next in Number 02-299, Entergy Louisiana versus Louisiana Public Service Commission.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
What is... what is the source of the rule that this is the sole remedy?
--It's the sole remedy under the tariff itself, Your Honor.
The... so the tariff itself provides that.
Yes.
Is... is the tariff provision meant to preclude any sort of a judicial remedy?
Yes, it would preclude a judicial remedy.
Well, there would be a judicial remedy if they disagreed with the... with... with FERC's determination.
Oh, absolutely, Your Honor.
They just couldn't go straight to the court.
--Yes.
Can I ask?
Well, at the time this--
I mean, if as you say it's only FERC, why didn't they just say from FERC?
--Well, it was... it was fairly prescient because this... this language I think dates from 1953, when there was the Federal Power Commission.
Oh, I see.
--But the... the key thing here is that it's undisputed that the LPSC can't amend the service agreement.
Got you.
Yes.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Well, does that... is that a death sentence, so to speak, if you find that the costs are trapped and unrecoverable?
That's correct, Your Honor.
You're... you're not talking about costs... trapped costs generally.
--That's right.
So the... the problem is that... not that the costs would be trapped, but that FERC has said it's not trapped.
That is... I... I think that... that--
So the real point is here FERC has said they can do it.
--There are two points.
And that's a FERC question, period.
That's right.
Could... could this be characterized as a question of a reasonable interpretation of the tariff, or you couldn't characterize the issue that way?
--There... there is a... an interpretation, an underlying question of interpretation, of the tariff, but beyond that, there's the question of whether the resulting charge was just and reasonable.
But--
--and that the resulting charge was unjust and unreasonable.
--But what Louisiana is saying, they... they're conceding that FERC has the authority, the exclusive authority, to prescribe what the division would be.
In the context of what the wholesale charge is or should be, the provision of the act is section 824d and... and 824e.
They're not regulating the wholesale rates is what... is the argument that will be made by the State.
--Justice Scalia, in fact, they were regulating the wholesale charge.
I thought the Court said in Mississippi Power & Light that once FERC sets a wholesale rate, a State may not conclude in setting retail rates that the FERC-approved wholesale rates are unreasonable.
--That... That's correct.
So I guess that's the law, isn't it?

--the only additional step that need be taken in this... in this case is to determine whether the fact that there is a dispute as to whether or not the FERC rate schedule was violated somehow puts the case within the State's jurisdiction.
But how is that different from the State determining that a retail rate is unreasonable?
We believe it's precisely the same.
So then there is nothing extra.
Our... our answer to that question is there is no difference.
So I have to see what the other side would say.
That's correct, Justice Breyer.
I... I take it you agree with Mr. Carpenter that the State can be heard on this issue as an intervenor who may raise the issue before FERC.
Not just as an intervenor.
I see.
--to FERC.
In any case, it can get to FERC if it has a gripe.
--The order 415 proceeding in 1997... that was resolved in 1997... shows exactly how this should happen.
No, but the answer to my question is yes, isn't it?
--Oh, yes, absolutely.
That's all I'm... that's all I'm--
--Well, it seems to me it's quite a different question.
Justice Scalia, the order 415 proceeding shows precisely the problem with that.

Must be a section of the FERC rules or regs or tariffs which says the company may... must... or must pass over to the company that has the higher number of generators a charge equal to the amount, da, da, da, that this particular thing we have before it gives the allocation for.
Well, the... the rate schedule has been approved--
Yes.
--by FERC and--
All right--
--there's a requirement--
--it says that in the rate schedule.
--and there's a requirement to the comply with rate schedule.
So the rate schedule of FERC says charge a rate--
That's right.
--based on this allocation.
That's right.
All right.
If the Court has no further questions.
I... I do.
Thank you.
We're... we're within about 15 feet of you, Mr. Fontham.
Unless the Court has any further questions, I have nothing else I need to add.
Thank you, Mr. Carpenter.
